Award.AwardTitle: How Does Brain Time Lead to Mind Time in Perception and Action?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to perceive time is innate to humans, but very little is known on the underlying psychological and neural mechanisms. Some peculiar daily life and laboratory phenomena where time appears to be frozen for a brief moment, termed "chronostasis," especially poses a challenge to cognitive neuroscientists. It may also be related to pathological experiences of time lapse in cases such as schizophrenia and drug-addicts. Chronostasis, which usually happens around the hundreds of millisecond range, could occur with or without action, given different perceptual contexts. This particular phenomenon could be a valuable window into how the brain constructs duration perception. With the support from National Science Foundation, Dr. Shinsuke Shimojo and colleagues will use electroencephalogram (EEG) along with a novel method to measure neural activity and its dynamics corresponding to this phenomenon. First, this project will provide further insights into why people perform a challenging task (for example, in sports or games) with concentrated attention sometimes experience "a flow of time." Second, the novel method could lead to a new neural activity index for clinical screening to understanding of mental disorders, because it is known that various types of patients, such as schizophrenics, autistic, and ADHD patients, have problems in time perception. The new knowledge of neural areas and dynamics may also inspire new programs and devices for training or rehabilitation. Third, the conclusions may potentially impact occupations whose performance relies on precise temporal judgments.

Our scientific hypothesis is that duration perception at the hundreds of milliseconds range is mediated by "hierarchical predictive coding," where both familiarity and novelty play a role in modulating perceived duration. The mechanism governing familiarity is likely "repetition suppression," i.e. a relatively automatic decay of neural responses by repetition; the mechanisms subserving novelty detection could be attention orienting. The researchers will isolate these factors with behavioral experiments, and then find corresponding neural correlates with EEG. Specifically, they will use a steady state visual evoked potential (SSVEP) approach to mark the short duration visual stimuli with a tagging temporal frequency. This will give them advantage in subsequent source localization and network connectivity analysis. They expect to discover interactions between low-level and high-level brain areas that co-decide duration perception, which will provide some clues to the ultimate mystery in behavioral neuroscience, that is, how we could experience time lapse, without having peripheral and specific sensory receptors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a world full of fleeting events, how could humans perceive durations as short as half a second? Unlike primary senses, there are no receptors for directly perceiving time. Does subsecond time perception result from the interpretation of memory traces in the primary senses, or the readings of an internal clock independent of primary senses? We tackled this debate by examining the mechanisms of two peculiar time expansion illusions (chronostasis) whose magnitude is typically about 10-15%. One illusion is that the first item in a series of identical items appears to last longer, which is termed debut chronostasis The other is that an unusual item appears to last longer, which is termed oddball chronostasis. To simplify the exploration, we started with visual stimuli to define physical duration.

For oddball chronostasis, we have found that an unusual item leads to subjective time expansion from three distinct mechanisms. Top-down attention is the inherent factor while bottom-up attention/ saliency and temporal preparation (anticipation) are factors contingent upon the item context. If perceptual memory traces are pertinent to perceived duration, then a basic phenomenon such as reduced neural activity from repeated items, should directly impact perceived duration. However, our experimental results have falsified such a possibility while corroborating the three candidate mechanisms aforementioned. Therefore, our investigation into oddball chronostasis favors the independent internal clock view over than the primary sense memory trace view.

For debut chronostasis, our experiments further elucidated that this time illusion is determined by a cognitive rather a perceptual factor, which is also against a primary sense memory trace view of time perception. Previously it was hypothesized that the first item among identical ones draw more attention or the subsequent ones are suppressed because of repetition. Our novel results showed that neither were true. To measure subjectively perceived duration, the most frequently used task is duration comparison between two items, where one item has fixed and the other has variable duration. Previous studies had only varied the duration of the first item in their tasks. We have found that simply by making the duration of the first item fixed, the illusion vanished. By contrast, a variable second item does not appear to last longer than the first or the third item. Neither the attention nor the repetition suppression hypotheses could explain this. Therefore, a new insight is that the first item plays a major role in updating the reference memory for time perception. We thus concluded that the cause of debut chronostasis is likely the uncertainty of duration reference memory. Another novel finding is that debut chronostasis also exists in auditory and even cross-modal cases, suggesting that the reference memory is at least to some extent independent of the primary senses. This is thus more in line with the independent internal clock view.

In summary, although the direct neural correlates of perceived duration have not been pinned down after several attempts, we did successfully identify multiple cognitive factors that govern our time perception in the sub-second range. These lead to new theoretical directions regarding how humans perceive time. Broadly speaking, attention and memory are the two major aspects of our internal state that regulate how long an event seems to have elapsed. In other words, time perception is hence a rather cognitive than perceptual process. Future studies may continue to unravel the neural correlates of each regulating mechanism, in hopes of revealing the neural mechanism of the subjective time itself.
